item.title: "Major" Dynasty Warriors: Origins DLC and Mystery Remaster In the Works
item.content:encoded:
Koei Tecmo has announced two major Dynasty Warriors projects as part of the celebrations for the series' 25th anniversary, and if you're a fan of old-school entries in the series, it looks like you're in luck.

First up, as revealed on Steam, a "large-scale" DLC expansion is in development for Dynasty Warriors: Origins. Koei Tecmo is remaining relatively tight-lipped about what that DLC pack might entail, but it's a "major" expansion, according to an accompanying trailer.

Not only is the DLC coming, but a remastered version of one of the series' past entries is also in the works. Again, we don't know which game is up for the remaster treatment, but given that titles like Dynasty Warriors 3 and 5 are fan favorites, it's likely one of these is the subject of Koei Tecmo's nostalgic attentions.

News of Dynasty Warriors: Origins' upcoming DLC comes a few months after Koei Tecmo revealed that the latest game in the large-scale hack-and-slash franchise has hit a million sales worldwide. Since that announcement was back in February, it's likely the game has picked up even more sales for itself in the interim.

Origins revolves around a "nameless hero in the Three Kingdoms", who will experience the "magnificent and alluring" story of this historical period (albeit through the lens of Dynasty Warriors' characteristic over-the-top action) as he hacks and slashes his way through legions of enemies.

The game offers a new spin on the usual blend of action and strategy that characterizes Dynasty Warriors, as well as a fresh take on the narrative that the series has revolved around since its inception in 2000.

You can check out the Dynasty Warriors 25th-anniversary trailer right here. It's pretty short, but it should spark a few memories if you've been with the series since the start.

Dynasty Warriors: Origins is available right now for PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: EDF and WWE Developer Yuke's Acquires Utawarerumono Studio Aquaplus
item.content:encoded:
WWE and Earth Defense Force developer Yuke's has acquired Japanese visual novel-focused studio Aquaplus, best known for games like To Heart, Utawarerumono, and White Album.

As spotted by Automaton Media, Yuke's announced the acquisition via its official Japanese website earlier today. The deal, which cost Yuke's around 784 million yen (around $5.3 million), also includes F.I.X. Records, a music label under Aquaplus' stewardship.

Naturally, as is customary in the corporate world, Yuke's is looking to leverage Aquaplus' expertise in the visual novel area in order to reach a new audience, and it'll be putting some of its own development heft behind the studio's ongoing projects.

If you're not familiar with Aquaplus, it's a Japanese visual novel-centric studio that's also responsible for the Leaf label, under which the company has published games like 1998's White Album and 1997's To Heart.

The aforementioned White Album was unavailable outside of Japan between its original 1998 release and 2023, when it was released for PC via Steam in the West, complete with an all-new official localization.

ToHeart, meanwhile, was remade earlier this year for PC and Switch, and the new version boasts all-new 3D scenes, improved visuals and gameplay, and a new set of voiceovers, although you can also choose to switch to the original cast if you prefer.

As for Yuke's, you probably know the studio's name best from the WWE 2K series, for which it was responsible between its inception in 2000 through to 2018, at which point 2K subsidiary Visual Concepts took over the series (with what can best be described as mixed results to start with).

Following the WWE 2K franchise switching to Visual Concepts, Yuke's worked on the official AEW tie-in game AEW: Fight Forever, and the studio is also responsible for this year's upcoming beat-'em-up Double Dragon Revive.

You may also know Yuke's from its work on the Earth Defense Force franchise; the developer worked on spinoffs like the World Brothers sub-series and 2019's Iron Rain.

Whether or not the acquisition of Aquaplus by Yuke's results in a change in either studio's operations remains to be seen, but I'd imagine it'll be business as usual. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: BioShock Remake Reportedly Canceled as BioShock 4 Struggles
item.content:encoded:
According to a new report, a BioShock remake that was in development at publisher 2K has been canceled, and the long-awaited BioShock 4 is currently struggling due to problems with its story.

As reported by Bloomberg's Jason Schreier, a remake of the original BioShock was being developed at 2K Games, although which development subsidiary was to handle the project is unclear. That's moot now, though, of course, since the project has been shut down.

Not only that, but BioShock 4, which was announced all the way back in late 2019 (and which has been rumored to take place in Antarctica in the 1960s), has run into its own spot of bother, with senior 2K executives reportedly unhappy with the direction of the game's story.

According to Schreier's report, a recent internal review concerning BioShock 4 at 2K resulted in executives expressing dismay with the narrative chosen by developer Cloud Chamber, although it's not clear exactly what they were displeased with.

As a result of that review, however, Kelley Gilmore was ousted from her role at the top of Cloud Chamber, and Hogarth de la Plante, who was previously serving as BioShock 4's creative director, will now serve in what Schreier calls "a publishing role".

Additionally, Cloud Chamber staffers were reportedly told by 2K that their studio needs to become "more agile and efficient" (that's Bloomberg's wording), which sounds like prime corporate speak for impending staff cuts.

2K told Bloomberg that while the current iteration of BioShock 4 is "good", the publisher is "committed to delivering a great [game]", and that it's currently "working closely with [Cloud Chamber] leadership" to achieve this goal.

Since BioShock 4 is struggling and the BioShock remake has been canned, it looks like BioShock fans' next great hope is Judas, Ken Levine and Ghost Story Games' upcoming narrative FPS.

Sadly, that game doesn't have a release date yet, so for now, it seems as though you'll have to content yourself with replaying the existing BioShock games. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
